comments.raw_text:
Whenever I reply to one of Roc's HTML emails that contains text quoted from other people, Thunderbird indents and single-quotes the quoted text instead of double- (or triple- or whatever) quoting it.

He seems to be using Gmail because the HTML is cluttered with Gmail classes. Not sure if the problem is Gmail's fault or Thunderbird's fault. IIRC, Netscape generated special nonstandard <blockquote> markup when quoting in email; maybe that's required for recognizing a <blockquote> as an email quote. The question is then whether Gmail should be generating that, or Thunderbird shouldn't be looking for that.

comments.raw_text:
Gmail does several thing _differently_ 
When composing in html mode using their formatting toolbar, quotes are inserted with styled blockquote tags.
IE
blockquote style=3D"margin: 0pt 0pt 0pt 0.8ex; border-left:=
 1px solid rgb(204, 204, 204); padding-left: 1ex;" class=3D"gmail_quote"

They also send multipart alternative _without_ the customary double ">>" for the quoted sections.

Gmail pretty much assumes that replies will be in html format. If you do reply in html the blockquote styles are retained.

If you attempt to reply in plaintext, you are out of luck unless you reply using html composition and add the html attribute (type="cite") to the quotes.
You can then choose Option>>Format>> send in plaintext and the quotes will be preserved.

comments.text:
Thanks for the workaround.

However, I'd prefer to be able to choose to reply to --and read-- plain text.  The fact that it is called "multipart/alternative" seems to imply that such choice should be offered.  See also bug 565949.
